EXECUTIVE SUMMARY:

Management at the Goodyear Tire & Rubber Company, is committed to protecting the environment and the health and safety of our associates, our customers, and the communities where we operate. The Houston Chemical Plant's Accidental Release Prevention programs prevent accidents at each stage of plant operation. New or expanded facilities are built to current engineering standards, and hazard reviews are conducted on all chemical processes. Process workers are trained and certified in detailed operating procedures. Equipment is regularly inspected to standards, and is an integral part of the preventative maintenance system. 

Coordinated emergency response actions between the Houston Chemical Plant and local emergency officials are planned and practiced. By working together, the emeregency response teams are prepared to take the necessary measures to protect the public if an incident occurs. 

FACILITY DESCRIPTION

The Goodyear Houston Chemical Plant was built in 1943 by the U.S. government to produce synthetic rubber.  After World War II, The Goodyear Tire & Rubber Company purchased the Houston plant from the government, and has since expanded and modernized the facility.

Synthetic rubber manufactured at the facility is called "Plioflex" rubber.  To produce it, two petrochemicals, butadiene and styrene are reacted with several chemical agents in a soap and water solution. The reaction of butadiene and styrene to produce rubber gives off heat, and the temperature of reaction is controlled by the coolant anhydrous ammonia.

Butadiene is a flammable substance that is stored under pressure in sufficient quantity to be regulated.  Anhydrous ammonia is also regulated.

ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION PROGRAM 

The prevention program is guided by the OSHA Process Safety Management (PSM) regulation, and applies to process operations containing the chemicals butadiene and anhydrous ammonia. Some of the more important aspects of the accidental release prevent

ion program are: 

1. Permitting systems for hot work, confoned space, and vehicle entry.
2. Process Hazard Analysis of processes containing butadiene and anhydrous ammonia.
3. Training and certification program.
4. Mechanical Integrity Program including:
Visual internal/external inspection of equipment.
Corrosion monitoring of vessels and piping.
Vibration analysis of rotating equipment.
Routine testing and maintenance of relief valves.

5. Written operating instructions that include safe upper and lower control limits, consequence of deviation, and emergency shutdown procedures. 
6. Leak detection and repair program; covering piping components that are monitored quarterly. 

FIVE YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY

The Goodyear Houston Chemical Plant has had no accidental releases of chemicals causing any known off-site environmental impacts in the last five years. 

EMERGENCY RESPOSE PROGRAM

The Goodyear Houston Chemical Plant is a member of the Channel Industries Mutual Aid organization (CIMA), which provides emergency response assistance from neighboring plants. Goodyear conducts training and participates in practice; with CIMA plant members.

The Goodyear emergency response teams are trained in fire fighting, rescue, hazardous materials response, and emergency medical care. 

Goodyear Houston is a active member of the Houston Local Emergency Planning Committee.

PLANNED IMPROVEMENTS

The Goodyear Houston Chemical Plant has programs and systems in place that result in continuous improvements in safety at the facility .
